https://trustmark.gtri.gatech.edu/operational-pilot/trustmark-definitions/ficam-loa-3-authentication-process-requirements/1.0/ https://trustmark.gtri.gatech.edu/operational-pilot/trustmark-definitions/ficam-loa-3-authentication-process-requirements/1.0/trustmark-reference/ FICAM LOA 3 Authentication Process Requirements 1.0 This Trustmark Definition adopts the LOA 3 Authentication Process trust criteria of the FICAM Trust Framework Provider Adoption Process. 2014-10-07T09:57:01 https://trustmark.gtri.gatech.edu/ Georgia Tech Research Institute PRIMARY TrustmarkFeedback@gtri.gatech.edu 404-407-8956 75 5th Street NW, Suite 900, Atlanta, GA 30308 Stakeholders of the U.S. federal notions of levels of assurance as defined by the National Institute of Standards and Technology and the FICAM TFS. Credential Service Providers that wish to assert identities to either federal relying parties or relying parties that utilize the U.S. federal notions of levels of assurance. U.S. federal relying parties and other relying parties that utilize the U.S. federal notions of levels of assurance. Current or prospective FICAM-approved trust framework providers (TFPs), or Trustmark Providers that specialize in assessments concerning the U.S. federal notions of levels of assurance.

Any organization or business entity may act as a Trustmark Provider for trustmarks under this Trustmark Definition.

]]>

Any individual employed or contracted by the Trustmark Provider may act as the assessor for trustmarks under this Trustmark Definition.

]]>

For any trustmark issued under this Trustmark Definition, the Trustmark Provider must revoke the trustmark upon any condition whereby one or more Conformance Criteria cease to be satisfied.

]]>

This Trustmark Definition requires no extension data.

]]> This document and the information contained herein is provided on an "AS IS" basis, and the Georgia Tech Research Institute disclaims all warranties, express or implied, including but not limited to any warranty that the use of the information herein will not infringe any rights or any implied warranties or merchantability or fitness for a particular purpose. In addition, the Georgia Tech Research Institute disclaims legal liability for any loss incurred as a result of the use or reliance on the document or the information contained herein. The Georgia Tech Research Institute (GTRI) has published this document with the support of the National Strategy for Trusted Identities in Cyberspace (NSTIC) via the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). The views expressed herein do not necessarily reflect the official policies of GTRI, NIST or NSTIC; nor does mention of trade names, commercial practices, or organizations imply endorsement by the U.S. Government. adopted authentication scheme / adopted scheme An open identity management standard that the ICAM assesses, approves, and scopes for use across the federal government. An adopted scheme meets all applicable ICAM requirements, as well as other federal statutes, regulations, and policies. In addition, the structured adoption process provides assurance to all ICAM participants that underlying identity assurance technologies are appropriate, robust, reliable, and secure.

]]> applicant A party undergoing the processes of registration and identity proofing.

]]> approved cryptographic method FIPS approved or NIST recommend. An algorithm or technique that is either (1) specified in a FIPS or NIST Recommendation, or (2) adopted in a FIPS or NIST Recommendation.

]]> authentication assertion A statement from a verifier to an RP that may contain identity and attribute information about a subscriber, as well as information about an authentication event that has been completed with the subscriber.

]]> authentication factor A category of tokens that is either "something you know" (e.g., a password), "something you have" (e.g., a cryptographic key), or "something you are" (e.g., a fingerprint).

]]> authentication protocol / authentication scheme A defined sequence of messages between a claimant and a verifier that demonstrates that the claimant has possession and control of a valid token to establish his/her identity, and optionally, demonstrates to the claimant that he or she is communicating with the intended verifier. An authentication protocol may also define the generation of an authentication assertion to be provided to an RP.

]]> authentication protocol run An exchange of messages between a claimant and a verifier that executes an authentication protocol and results in authentication, or authentication failure, between the two parties.

]]> claimant A party whose identity is to be verified using an authentication protocol.

]]> credential An object or data structure that authoritatively binds an identity (and optionally, additional attributes) to a token possessed and controlled by a subscriber. A credential may be maintained by the subscriber to which the credential was issued or by the CSP that issued the credential.

]]> credential service provider CSP An entity that issues or registers subscriber tokens and issues credentials to subscribers (i.e, a CSP conducts the issuance process). A CSP may encompass RAs and verifiers that it operates. A CSP may be an independent third party, or may issue credentials for its own use.

]]> established policy, procedure, or practice statement A policy, procedure, or practice statement that has been formally adopted and put into use by an entity.

]]> established technical capability The ability to accurately implement and maintain, as part of normal business operations, a technical mechanism for achieving some goal.

]]> external RA designee An RA designee that is governed by an entity other than the CSP that it serves.

]]> external verifier designee A verifier designee that is governed by an entity other the CSP that it serves.

]]> Federal Identity, Credential, and Access Management FICAM An initiative for implementing ICAM principles within the U.S. Federal Government.

]]> Federal Identity, Credential, and Access Management Trust Framework Solutions FICAM TFS The federated identity framework for the U.S. Federal Government.

]]> Identity, Credential, and Access Management ICAM A federal program that focuses on addressing challenges, pressing issues, and design requirements for digital identity, credential, and access management and defining and promoting consistency across approaches for implementing ICAM programs as reflected in the FICAM Roadmap & Implementation Guidance

]]> Identity, Credential, and Access Management Sub-Committee ICAMSC A committee established in 2008 under the Federal CIO Council's Information Security and Identity Management Committee (ISIMC) and tasked with aligning the identity management activities of the Federal Government..

]]> identity proofing The process by which a CSP and an RA collect and verify information about a person for the purpose of issuing credentials to that person.

]]> identity provider IDP A system used to perform the token / credential validation functions of a CSP and the authentication and assertion issuance functions of a verifier.

]]> issuance The process of issuing tokens or credentials to a subscriber of a CSP.

]]> level of assurance LOA The degree of confidence in the vetting process used to establish the identity of an individual to whom the credential was issued and the degree of confidence that the individual who uses the credential is the individual to whom the credential was issued. Also, see the use of assurance in [OMB M-04-04].

]]> LOA 2 level of assurance 2. As defined in [OMB M-04-04], LOA 2 means "Some confidence in an asserted identity's validity". This is in contrast to levels 1, 3, and 4, which mean "little or no", "high", and "very high", respectively, in regards to assurance in an asserted identity's validity.

]]> LOA 2 adopted authentication scheme An adopted authentication scheme approved for use at LOA 2.

]]> LOA 2 applicant An applicant that has applied to go through an LOA 2 registration and issuance process sequence.

]]> LOA 2 authentication assertion An authentication assertion that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 authentication protocol An authentication protocol that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 credential A credential that that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 identity proofing An identity proofing process that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 issuance An issuance process that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 registration A registration process that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 registration and issuance A sequence of registration and issuance processes that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 shared secret file A shared secret file that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 subscriber A subscriber that has gone through a LOA 2 registration and issuance process sequence.

]]> LOA 2 token A token that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 token authenticator A token authenticator generated by an LOA 2 token.

]]> LOA 3 level of assurance 3. As defined in [OMB M-04-04], LOA 3 means "high confidence in an asserted identity's validity". This is in contrast to levels 1, 2, and 4, which mean "little or no", "some", and "very high", respectively, in regards to assurance in an asserted identity's validity.

]]> LOA 3 adopted authentication scheme An adopted authentication scheme approved for use at LOA 3.

]]> LOA 3 applicant An applicant that has applied to go through an LOA 3 registration and issuance process sequence.

]]> LOA 3 authentication assertion An authentication assertion that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 authentication protocol An authentication protocol that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 credential A credential that that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 identity proofing An identity proofing process that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 issuance An issuance process that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 registration A registration process that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 registration and issuance A sequence of registration and issuance processes that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 shared secret file A shared secret file that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 subscriber A subscriber that has gone through a LOA 3 registration and issuance process sequence.

]]> LOA 3 token A token that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 token authenticator A token authenticator generated by an LOA 3 token.

]]> multi-factor token A token that uses two or more factors to achieve authentication.

]]> multi-stage authentication An authentication scheme, or series of authentication schemes used together, in which one token is used to obtain a second token.

]]> multi-token authentication An authentication scheme in which the claimant presents token authenticators generated by two or more tokens (not using a multi-stage process) to prove his or her identity to the verifier. The combination of tokens is characterized by the combination of factors used by the tokens (both inherent in the manifestation of the tokens, and those used to activate the tokens).

]]> NIST National Institute of Standards and Technology.

]]> OMB United States Office of Management and Budget.

]]> personally identifiable information PII Information which can be used to distinguish or trace an individual's identity, such as their name, social security number, biometric records, etc. alone, or when combined with other personal or identifying information which is linked or linkable to a specific individual, such as date and place of birth, mother's maiden name, etc.

]]> policy A statement of criteria to which an entity is expected to conform.

]]> practice statement A formal statement of the practices followed by a party. A practice statement usually describes the policies and practices of the party and can become legally binding.

]]> procedure A sequence of steps that achieves some stated goal.

]]> process See "procedure"

]]> RA designee An RA designated by a particular CSP to conduct LOA 2 registration or LOA 2 identity proofing processes on behalf of that CSP. An RA designee may be governed directly by the relying CSP (e.g., a department or business unit of the CSP), or by an entity external to the relying CSP.

]]> registration authority RA An entity that establishes and vouches for the identity or attributes of a subscriber to a CSP. The RA may be an integral part of a CSP, or it may be independent of a CSP, but it has a relationship to the CSP(s). It is important for an RA to be trusted by the CSPs and applicants that it serves and RPs that rely on the identity proofing that it does.

]]> registration and issuance The sequence of the registration and issuance processes.

]]> registration The process through which an applicant applies to become a subscriber of a CSP and an RA validates the identity of the applicant on behalf of the CSP. In other words, registration includes identity proofing and refers to the registration by an RA of the results of performing identity proofing on an applicant.

]]> relying party RP An entity that relies upon a subscriber's credentials or verifier's assertion of an identity, typically to process a transaction or grant access to an information system.

]]> shared secret A secret used in authentication that is known to the claimant and the verifier.

]]> shared secret file A file held by a CSP or verifier that contains secrets held between the CSP or verifier and its subscribers or claimants.

]]> single-factor token A token that uses one of the three factors to achieve authentication.

]]> single-token authentication An authentication scheme in which the claimant presents a single token authenticator to prove his or her identity to the verifier.

]]> subscriber A party who has received a credential or token from a CSP.

]]> TFPAP Trust Framework Provider Adoption Process, v2.0.2. See [TFPAP].

]]> token Something that a claimant possess and controls (typically a cryptographic module or password) that is used to authenticate the claimant's identity.

]]> token authenticator The output value generated by a token. This value is one that is provided to a protocol stack to prove that a claimant possess and controls a token. Protocol messages sent to a verifier are dependent upon the token authenticator, but may or may not explicitly contain it.

]]> verifier An entity that verifies a claimant's identity by verifying the claimant's possession and control of a token using an authentication protocol. To do this, the verifier may also need to validate credentials that link the token and identity and check their status.

]]> verifier designee A verifier designated by a particular CSP to conduct LOA 2 authentication protocol run processes on behalf of that CSP. A verifier designee may be governed by the CSP (e.g., a department or business unit of the CSP), or by an entity external to the CSP.

]]> SP 800-63-2 NIST SP 800-63-2: Electronic Authentication Guideline, August, 2013 OMB M-04-04 Office of Management and Budget Memorandum M-04-04, December 16, 2003 TFPAP LOA 3 FICAM TFS Trust Framework Provider Adoption Process for All Levels of Assurance, v2.0.2, March, 14, 2014, Appendix A-3: Assurance Level 3 1 Resist the threat of online guessing The CSP MUST ensure that its LOA 3 verifier designees protect against an attacker performing repeated logon trials on LOA 3 authentication protocol runs by guessing possible values of the token authenticator, and thereby resist the threat of online guessing.

]]> Authentication Process Table, Item 1]]> Section 8: Authentication Process]]> 2 Resist the threat of replay The CSP MUST ensure that its LOA 3 verifier designees protect against an attacker being able to replay messages previously captured from LOA 3 authentication protocol runs (between a legitimate claimant and a verifier) to authenticate as that claimant to the verifier, and thereby resist the threat of replay.

]]> Authentication Process Table, Item 2]]> Section 8: Authentication Process]]> 3 Resist the threat of session hijacking The CSP MUST ensure that its LOA 3 verifier designees protect against an attacker being able to take over an already authenticated LOA 3 session by eavesdropping on or predicting the value of authentication cookies used to mark HTTP requests sent by the subscriber, and thereby resist the threat of session hijacking.

]]> Authentication Process Table, Item 3]]> Section 8: Authentication Process]]> 4 Resist the threat of eavesdropping The CSP MUST ensure that is LOA 3 verifier designees uses approved cryptography to protect against attacks on LOA 3 authentication protocol runs in which an attacker listens passively to the authentication protocol run to capture information that can be used in a subsequent active attack to masquerade as the claimant, and thereby resist the threat of eavesdropping.

]]> Authentication Process Table, Item 4]]> Section 8: Authentication Process]]> 5 Resist the threat of phishing The CSP MUST ensure that its LOA 3 verifier designees resist the threat of phishing on LOA 3 subscribers by protecting against phishing attacks in which a subscriber is lured to interact with a counterfeit verifier and tricked into revealing information that can be used to masquerade as that subscriber to the real verifier.

]]> Authentication Process Table, Item 5]]> Section 8: Authentication Process]]> 6 Resist the threat of pharming The CSP MUST ensure that its LOA 3 verifier designees resist the threat of pharming on LOA 3 subscribers by protecting against pharming attacks in which an attacker corrupts an infrastructure service such as DNS (Domain Name Service) causing a subscriber to be misdirected to a forged verifier, and revealing sensitive information, downloading harmful software or contributing to a fraudulent act.

]]> Authentication Process Table, Item 5]]> Section 8: Authentication Process]]> 7 Weakly resist the threat of man-in-the-middle attacks The CSP MUST ensure that its LOA 3 verifier designees protect against attacks on LOA 3 authentication protocol runs in which the attacker positions himself in between the claimant and verifier so that he can intercept and alter data traveling between them, and thereby weakly resist the threat of a man-in-the-middle attack. Note that a protocol is said to be weakly resistant to man-in-the-middle attacks if it provides a mechanism for the claimant to determine whether he or she is interacting with the real verifier, but still leaves the opportunity for the non-vigilant claimant to reveal a token authenticator (to an unauthorized party) that can be used to masquerade as the claimant to the real verifier.

]]> Authentication Process Table, Item 6]]> Section 8: Authentication Process]]> 8 Use of multi-factor authentication The CSP MUST ensure that its LOA 3 verifier designees use at least two authentication factors when authenticating claimants during an LOA 3 authentication protocol runs.

]]> Authentication Process Table, Item 7]]> Section 8: Authentication Process]]> 9 Validate claimants' possession of tokens The CSP MUST ensure that successful LOA 3 authentication requires a claimant to prove, through a secure, cryptographic authentication protocol, that he or she actually possesses and controls an LOA 3 token or multiple tokens that combined are graded at LOA 3.

]]> Authentication Process Table, Item 8]]> Section 8: Authentication Process]]> 10 Use of strong cryptographic mechanisms The CSP MUST ensure that strong cryptographic mechanisms are used to protect token secrets and authenticators during LOA 3 authentication protocol runs.

]]> Authentication Process Table, Item 9]]> Section 8: Authentication Process]]> 11 Disclosure of long-term shared secrets The CSP MUST ensure that long-term LOA 3 shared authentication secrets, if used, are never revealed to any party except the claimant with whom the secret is registered and the CSP. However, session (temporary) shared secrets may be provided to verifier designees by the CSP, possibly via the claimant.

]]> Authentication Process Table, Item 10]]> Section 8: Authentication Process]]> 12 Transmission of plaintext passwords The CSP MUST ensure that plaintext passwords and secrets are not transmitted across a network during LOA 3 authentication protocol runs.

]]> Authentication Process Table, Item 11]]> Section 8: Authentication Process]]> 13 Unique identification of subscribers The CSP MUST ensure that LOA 3 authentication protocols provide sufficient information to its verifier designees for uniquely identifying each LOA 3 subscriber and the appropriate registration information that was provided by each subscriber at the time of registration, and verified by an RA designee in the issuance of the token and credential.

]]> Authentication Process Table, Item 12]]> Section 8: Authentication Process]]> 14 Protection of session data The CSP MUST ensure the protection of session data exchanged between the claimant and the relying party after a successful LOA 3 authentication.

]]> Authentication Process Table, Item 13]]> Section 8: Authentication Process]]> 15 Use of approved cryptographic techniques The CSP MUST ensure that only approved cryptographic techniques are used for all operations of LOA 3 authentication protocols including the transfer of session data.

]]> Authentication Process Table, Item 13]]> Section 8: Authentication Process]]> For assessment steps that require the verification that there are established policies or procedures that demonstrate conformance to a particular conformance criterion, there is an implied requirement to verify that there are no established policies or procedures that demonstrate non-conformance to that criterion. This can be facilitated by documenting references to sections of established policies and procedures that explicitly enumerate the entirety of the relevant items that need to be verified for conformance.

To answer an assessment step as not applicable, the assessor must document references to, and explanatory annotations of, sections of established policies or procedures of the Trustmark Applicant, its RA designees, or its CSP designees, that provide supporting evidence of why the assessment step should be answered as not applicable.

Assessors should use [SP 800-63-2 Authn Proc] as a guide for determining acceptable threat mitigation mechanisms.

]]> 1 Policy for resisting the threat of online guessing Does the trustmark applicant and its verifier designees have established policies or procedures that demonstrate that they resist the threat of online guessing during LOA 3 authentication protocol as required? Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 2 Technical capabilities for resisting the threat of online guessing Does the trustmark applicant and its verifier designees have established technical capabilities that enable them to resist the threat of online guessing on LOA 3 authentication protocols as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 3 Policy for resisting the threat of replay Does the trustmark applicant and its verifier designees have established policies or procedures that demonstrate that they resist the threat of replay of LOA 3 authentication protocol runs as required? Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 4 Technical capabilities for resisting the threat of replay Does the trustmark applicant and its verifier designees have established technical capabilities that enable them to resist the threat of replay of LOA 3 authentication protocol runs as required? Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> 14 Technical capabilities for resisting the threat of man-in-the-middle attacks Does the trustmark applicant and its verifier designees have established technical capabilities that enable them to resist the threat of man-in-the-middle attacks during LOA 3 authentication protocol runs as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 15 Policy for the use of multi-factor authentication Does the trustmark applicant and its verifier designees have established policies or procedures that demonstrate that they use multi-factor authentication during LOA 3 authentication protocol runs as required? Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 16 Technical capabilities the use of multi-factor authentication Does the trustmark applicant and its verifier designees have established technical capabilities that enable them to use multi-factor authentication during LOA 3 authentication protocol runs as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 17 Policy for validating claimants' possession of tokens Does the trustmark applicant and its verifier designees have established policies or procedures that demonstrate that they validate claimants' possession of tokens during LOA 3 authentication protocol runs as required? Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> 18 Technical capabilities for validating claimants' possession of tokens Does the trustmark applicant and its verifier designees have established technical capabilities that enable them to validate claimants' possession of tokens during LOA 3 authentication protocol runs as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 19 Policy for the use of strong cryptographic mechanisms Does the trustmark applicant and its verifier designees have established policies or procedures that demonstrate that they use strong cryptographic mechanisms during LOA 3 authentication protocol runs as required? Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> 26 Technical capabilities for the unique identification of subscribers Does the trustmark applicant and its verifier designees have established technical capabilities that enable them to uniquely identify subscribers during LOA 3 authentication protocol runs as required? Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> yes(ALL)
